pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 313, 386, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 890, 403]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 890, 465]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 555, 491]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 764, 535]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 631, 90]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical can is rolled along the ruler shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 100, 875, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 320, 267]]<|/det|>
The can rolls over twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 594, 297]]<|/det|>
What is the circumference (distance all round) of the can?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 707, 323]]<|/det|>
**A** 13 cm **B** 14 cm **C** 26 cm **D** 28 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 351, 95, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 351, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
Drops of water are dripping steadily from a tap (faucet). The diagram shows a measuring cylinder which has collected 120 drops of water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 392, 590, 744]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 881, 772]]<|/det|>
How many drops in total will have been collected when the measuring cylinder reads \(10 \text{cm}^3?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 783, 136, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 783, 178, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>48</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 783, 344, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 783, 420, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>60</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 783, 522, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 783, 687, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>180</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 783, 688, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 783, 688, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>300</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 830, 95, 847]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 829, 740, 846]]<|/det|>
In a race, a car travels 60 times around a 3.6km track. This takes 2.4 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 859, 434, 876]]<|/det|>
What is the average speed of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 887, 735, 904]]<|/det|>
<pre>A 1.5km/h B 90km/h C 144km/h D 216km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 97, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 73, 774, 91]]<|/det|> A metal block is heated until it is completely melted. It is then allowed to solidify. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 103, 680, 121]]<|/det|> What happens to the mass of the metal during the changes of state? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 133, 477, 276]]<|/det|>
mass during meltingmass during solidification
Adecreasesincreases
Bincreasesdecreases
Cincreasesstays constant
Dstays constantstays constant
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 305, 97, 323]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 305, 497, 322]]<|/det|> Two objects X and Y are placed on a balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 343, 352]]<|/det|> The balance tilts as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 363, 663, 444]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 712, 477]]<|/det|> What does this show about the masses and weights of objects X and Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 488, 645, 616]]<|/det|>
massesweights
AX has less mass than YX has less weight than Y
BX has less mass than YX has more weight than Y
CX has the same mass as YX has less weight than Y
DX has the same mass as YX has more weight than Y
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 644, 94, 663]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 562, 662]]<|/det|> A stone has a volume of \(0.50 \text{cm}^3\) and a mass of \(2.0 \text{g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 674, 390, 691]]<|/det|> What is the density of the stone? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 702, 248, 720]]<|/det|> **A** \(0.25g / cm^3\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 730, 238, 747]]<|/det|> **B** \(1.5g / cm^3\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 757, 238, 774]]<|/det|> **C** \(2.5g / cm^3\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 783, 238, 800]]<|/det|> **D** \(4.0g / cm^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 777, 91]]<|/det|>
Passengers are not allowed to stand on the upper deck of double-decker buses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[317, 100, 675, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 246, 220, 263]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 275, 140, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 275, 559, 292]]<|/det|>
They would cause the bus to become less stable.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 141, 319]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 301, 489, 318]]<|/det|>
They would cause the bus to slow down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 328, 140, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 327, 566, 345]]<|/det|>
They would increase the kinetic energy of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 141, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 354, 549, 370]]<|/det|>
They would lower the centre of mass of the bus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 399, 94, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 399, 531, 415]]<|/det|>
On which ball is a non-zero resultant force acting?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 425, 760, 730]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 761, 94, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 603, 777]]<|/det|>
Electricity can be obtained from different energy resources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 790, 839, 807]]<|/det|>
Which energy resource is used to obtain electricity without producing heat to boil water?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 819, 191, 835]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 819, 191, 835]]<|/det|>
coal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 846, 188, 862]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 846, 186, 863]]<|/det|>
gas

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 873, 260, 888]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 873, 260, 888]]<|/det|>
hydroelectric

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 898, 218, 914]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 898, 217, 913]]<|/det|>
nuclear

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 803, 107]]<|/det|>
A ball is dropped on to a hard surface and bounces. It does not bounce all the way but it started, so it has less gravitational potential energy than when it started.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 114, 660, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 294, 406, 312]]<|/det|>
What happens to the 'lost' energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 323, 136, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 323, 537, 341]]<|/det|>
It is converted into chemical and strain energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 133, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 350, 583, 367]]<|/det|>
It is converted into internal (heat) energy and sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 376, 673, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 374, 674, 392]]<|/det|>
It is destroyed as the ball rises upwards after hitting the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 517, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 401, 517, 418]]<|/det|>
It is destroyed when the ball hits the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 444, 107, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 401, 462]]<|/det|>
What does a barometer measure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 320, 490]]<|/det|>
<pre>A atmospheric density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 334, 516]]<|/det|>
<pre>B atmospheric pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 264, 543]]<|/det|>
<pre>C liquid density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 552, 277, 568]]<|/det|>
<pre>D liquid pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 596, 107, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 596, 693, 613]]<|/det|>
In which position would a boy exert the most pressure on the ground?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 624, 292, 640]]<|/det|>
<pre>A lying on his back

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 255, 666]]<|/det|>
<pre>B sitting down

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 676, 325, 692]]<|/det|>
<pre>C standing on one foot

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 702, 324, 718]]<|/det|>
<pre>D standing on two feet

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 816, 106]]<|/det|> On a warm day, a swimmer climbs out of a swimming pool into the open air and water from his skin. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 880, 151]]<|/det|> As the water evaporates, which molecules escape into the air first and what happens to average speed of the remaining water molecules? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 576, 308]]<|/det|>
first molecules to escapeaverage speed of the remaining molecules
Aleast energeticdecreases
Bleast energeticincreases
Cmost energeticdecreases
Dmost energeticincreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 336, 107, 354]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 620, 354]]<|/det|> Some air is trapped inside a metal can with a tightly fitting lid. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 363, 626, 558]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 572, 920, 604]]<|/det|> When the can is heated strongly behind a safety screen, the lid is blown off by the increased pressure inside the can. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 617, 636, 634]]<|/det|> What causes the increase in pressure of the air inside the can? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 647, 568, 663]]<|/det|> **A** The air molecules expand and take up more room. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 674, 465, 689]]<|/det|> **B** The air molecules move more quickly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 699, 572, 714]]<|/det|> **C** The number of molecules inside the can increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 570, 740]]<|/det|> **D** The volume occupied by the molecules decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 770, 107, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 770, 512, 786]]<|/det|> A solid object has a very large thermal capacity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 798, 304, 813]]<|/det|> What does this mean? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 826, 712, 842]]<|/det|> **A** A large amount of energy is needed to make the object become hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 853, 650, 868]]<|/det|> **B** A large amount of energy is needed to make the object melt. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 879, 712, 894]]<|/det|> **C** A small amount of energy is needed to make the object become hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 904, 652, 920]]<|/det|> **D** A small amount of energy is needed to make the object melt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 608, 91]]<|/det|>
A hot drink is left in a room that is at a temperature of \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 536, 121]]<|/det|>
What has happened to the drink after ten minutes?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 312, 149]]<|/det|>
A Its density is lower.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 160, 374, 176]]<|/det|>
B Its internal energy is lower.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 185, 425, 201]]<|/det|>
C Its particles have equal energies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 211, 413, 227]]<|/det|>
D Its particles move more quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 255, 107, 273]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
An engineer wants to fix a steel washer on to a steel rod. The rod is just too big to fit into the hole of the washer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[223, 298, 772, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 393, 536, 410]]<|/det|>
How can the engineer fit the washer on to the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 480, 438]]<|/det|>
A Cool the washer and put it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 769, 465]]<|/det|>
B Cool the washer and rod to the same temperature and push them together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 495, 491]]<|/det|>
C Heat the rod and then place it in the hole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 501, 540, 517]]<|/det|>
D Heat the washer and then place it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 534, 90]]<|/det|> A rod is made of copper and wood joined together. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 101, 721, 242]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 259, 616, 276]]<|/det|> The rod is heated at the join in the centre for about a minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 289, 860, 306]]<|/det|> At which labelled point will the temperature be lowest, and at which point will it be highest? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 318, 432, 463]]<|/det|>
lowest temperaturehighest temperature
APQ
BPR
CSP
DSR
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 492, 107, 509]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 492, 920, 524]]<|/det|> Two plastic cups are placed one inside the other. Hot water is poured into the inner cup and a lid is put on top, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 534, 660, 680]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 692, 350, 707]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 720, 141, 737]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 720, 610, 737]]<|/det|> Heat loss by radiation is prevented by the small air gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 746, 141, 764]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 746, 544, 763]]<|/det|> No heat passes through the sides of either cup. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 772, 141, 790]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 772, 714, 789]]<|/det|> The bench is heated by convection from the bottom of the outer cup. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 798, 141, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 798, 560, 815]]<|/det|> The lid is used to reduce heat loss by convection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 693, 91]]<|/det|> Which row shows the nature of light waves, sound waves and X-rays? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 103, 567, 228]]<|/det|>
light wavessound wavesX-rays
Alongitudinallongitudinaltransverse
Blongitudinaltransverselongitudinal
Ctransverselongitudinaltransverse
Dtransversetransverselongitudinal
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 259, 107, 276]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 787, 276]]<|/det|> The diagram shows plane water waves passing through a narrow gap in a barrier. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 285, 596, 450]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 465, 540, 482]]<|/det|> The waves spread out on the far side of the barrier. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 496, 487, 513]]<|/det|> Which property of waves does this illustrate? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 524, 238, 540]]<|/det|> A diffraction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 551, 232, 566]]<|/det|> B reflection <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 578, 232, 592]]<|/det|> C refraction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 228, 618]]<|/det|> D vibration

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 667, 92]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows radiation from a lamp passing through a prism.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 823, 106]]<|/det|> A converging lens in a projector is used to make an enlarged image of a small piece of screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 880, 135]]<|/det|> At which labelled point could the piece of film be placed so that the lens produces this image? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 145, 880, 387]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 420, 107, 439]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 920, 453]]<|/det|> A girl stands at a distance from a large building. She claps her hands and a short time later hears an echo. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 657, 483]]<|/det|> Why is an echo produced when the sound waves hit the building? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 420, 510]]<|/det|> **A** The sound waves are absorbed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 420, 536]]<|/det|> **B** The sound waves are diffracted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 547, 415, 562]]<|/det|> **C** The sound waves are reflected. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 572, 415, 588]]<|/det|> **D** The sound waves are refracted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 616, 107, 634]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 858, 634]]<|/det|> Three loudspeakers vibrate at different frequencies of 5 hertz, 25 kilohertz and 50 kilohertz. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[290, 642, 705, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 736, 870, 753]]<|/det|> Which row shows whether the vibrations from each loudspeaker can be heard by a human? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 765, 494, 893]]<|/det|>
5 hertz25 kilohertz50 kilohertz
Anonono
Bnoyesno
Cyesnoyes
Dyesyesyes

The iron bar to become magnetised. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 114, 715, 164]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 692, 193]]<|/det|> Which magnetic pole is induced at X and how is the iron bar affected? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 205, 504, 333]]<|/det|>
pole inducedeffect on iron bar

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 885, 478]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 684, 799, 702]]<|/det|>
to allow a large current in the relay coil to control a smaller current in the motor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 711, 139, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 711, 789, 728]]<|/det|>
to allow a small current in the relay coil to control a larger current in the motor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 738, 610, 755]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 764, 801, 781]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 764, 801, 781]]<|/det|>
to disconnect the battery from the motor automatically if too much current flows

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 814, 91]]<|/det|> The diagram shows some parts of a cathode-ray tube which is producing cathode ray <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 100, 687, 205]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 219, 495, 236]]<|/det|> Which is a correct description of the cathode? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 247, 300, 264]]<|/det|> A negative and cool <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 274, 294, 290]]<|/det|> B negative and hot <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 294, 316]]<|/det|> C positive and cool <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 285, 342]]<|/det|> D positive and hot <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 370, 107, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 370, 919, 403]]<|/det|> When measuring the emissions from a radioactive rock brought into the laboratory, a teacher mentions that background radiation must be taken into account. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 416, 404, 432]]<|/det|> What is this background radiation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 594, 460]]<|/det|> A infra-red radiation from warm objects in the laboratory <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 412, 486]]<|/det|> B infra-red radiation from the Sun <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 496, 724, 513]]<|/det|> C ionising radiation from the radioactive rock brought into the laboratory <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 522, 764, 538]]<|/det|> D ionising radiation in the laboratory when the radioactive rock is not present <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 567, 107, 585]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 567, 750, 584]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the paths of three different types of radiation, X, Y and Z. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 593, 714, 737]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 752, 559, 768]]<|/det|> Which row in the table correctly identifies X, Y and Z? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 781, 574, 908]]<|/det|>

<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 160, 440, 177]]<|/det|>
It has more electrons than protons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 186, 138, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 186, 438, 204]]<|/det|>
